documents.text:
Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 103   Filed 08/05/21   Page 1 of 10
 
1  AARON D. FORD 
  Attorney General 
2  D. Randall Gilmer, Bar No. 14001 
  Chief Deputy Attorney General 
3  Douglas R. Rands, Bar No. 3572 
  Senior Deputy Attorney General 
4  Office of the Attorney General 
100 N. Carson Street 
5  Carson City, NV 89701  
(775) 684-1150 
6  (775) 684-1108 (fax)  
drands@ag.nv.gov 
7  drgilmer@ag.nv.gov 
 
8  Attorneys for the  
Nevada Department of Corrections 
9   
 
10  UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
 
11  DISTRICT OF NEVADA 
 
12  * * * * * 
 
13  IN RE: HCV PRISON LITIGATION  Case No:  3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB 
   
14     
                JOINT QUARTERLY REPORT  
15   
 
16   
   
17 
18     Pursuant to this Court’s Order (ECF No. 79) and the Consent Judgment (ECF No. 80) 
19  (referred to as “Consent Judgment” or “Consent Decree”), the Parties submit this Joint Quarterly 
20  Report (“Report”) as part of the Court’s ongoing monitoring obligations.  
21  MEMORANDUM OF POINTS AND AUTHORITIES 
22  I.  OVERVIEW 
23  For the third reporting period, the Defendants represent that the fundamental aspects of the 
24  Consent Decree are in place and are operating as envisioned. However, there is a delay in scaling 
25  up the treatment due what NDOC represents is provider availability. NDOC contends that this has 
26  and will be, largely, mitigated by the new directive to write the prescriptions by the providers at 
27  each institution. As detailed below, Class counsel has significant concerns about delays and the 
28  ability of Defendants to meet the upcoming deadline.  
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 103   Filed 08/05/21   Page 2 of 10
 
1  The Parties have been able to work together to improve NDOC’s public health education 
2  efforts about HCV, which has already resulted in persons who have previously refused testing 
3  getting tested.  
4  This Report does not request relief or other intervention by the Court at this time. Class 
5  Counsel requests that a status conference be set shortly after the Consent Decree’s October 29, 
6  2021, deadline to treat class members. 
7  II.  STANDARD OF CARE 
8  The Parties have not identified any changes to the medical standard of care for HCV that 
9  would warrant alterations of the Consent Decree. The HCV Guidelines of the AASLD and the 
10  IDSA  were  updated  on  August  27,  2020,  and  continue  to  recommend  direct-acting  antiviral 
11  treatment. https://www.hcvguidelines.org.  
12  III.  TESTING  
13  Paragraph 32 of the Consent Decree requires Defendants to “test all inmates in the custody 
14  of NDOC for HCV by December 31, 2020.” (ECF No. 80). Defendants report that all inmates that 
15  were in NDOC’s physical custody as of December 31, 2020, have been tested. Defendants also 
16  report  that  inmates  that  are  new  to  NDOC  or  inmates  that  have  returned  from  out  of  state 
17  placements are still in the process of being tested and are being tested on an ongoing basis.  
18  Paragraph 34 of the Consent Decree requires Defendants to “screen and prioritize all Class 
19  Members using the criteria in the revised version of MD 219.” (ECF No. 80). Defendants report 
20  that all inmates with known test results have been prioritized. Inmates that still need be tested, as set 
21  forth above, will be prioritized as the results become known.  
22  Class Counsel has suggested that, given the lower-than-expected number of inmates with 
23  chronic HCV, Defendants should not delay the provision of treatment by waiting for the medical 
24  tests that may be used for prioritization but not for treatment. Class Counsel understand that Dr. 
25  Minev is in agreement with this strategy and has instructed the providers accordingly.  
26  /// 
27  /// 
28  /// 
 
2 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 103   Filed 08/05/21   Page 3 of 10
 
1  IV.  ONGOING MONITORING 
2  Paragraph  40  of  the  Consent  Decree  (ECF  No.  80)  requires  Defendants  to  provide 
3  information for the following categories: 
4  a.  The number of inmates tested/screened during the reporting period 
5  Defendants report that, between April 30, 2021, and July 27, 2021, 1,122 inmates have 
6  been tested for Hepatitis C.   
7  Class Counsel has inquired as to the relatively high number of tests for this quarter and are 
8  awaiting further information from Defendants. Class Counsel notes that in the Q1 and Q2 status 
9  reports, Defendants reported 803 and 806 inmates were tested respectively. (See ECF No. 84, p. 
10  3:22; see also ECF No. 86, p. 3:21.)    
11  b.  The number of inmates who tested positive for HCV during the reporting period 
12  (including the date on which each inmate tested positive for HCV) 
13  Defendants report that between April 30, 2021, and July 27, 2021, 74 inmates tested 
14  positive for HCV. The attached spreadsheet includes information on the date of each positive test. 
15  Exhibit A.  
16  c.  The number of inmates who began receiving DAA Treatment (with an indication of 
17  which type of DAA Treatment was provided and the date on which DAA Treatment 
18  was initiated) during the reporting period 
19  Defendants report that between April 30, 2021, and July 27, 2021, 74 inmates have begun 
20  DAA treatment. The attached spreadsheet includes information on the date treatment began and the 
21  type of treatment provided. Exhibit B.  
22  d.  The number of inmates who concluded their course of DAA Treatment (with an 
23  indication of which type of DAA Treatment was provided and the date on which DAA 
24  Treatment was concluded) during the reporting period. 
25  Defendants report that between April 30, 2021, and July 27, 2021, 104 inmates completed 
26  their treatment while in custody. 5 Inmates unexpectedly paroled mid-treatment between April 30, 
27  2021, and July 27, 2021 Inmates who were on their last month of treatment were issued their last 
28  bottle of medication upon discharge and were instructed to follow-up with their primary care 
 
3 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 103   Filed 08/05/21   Page 4 of 10
 
1  providers and/or local  health department. However, inmates who paroled during the first two 
2  months of treatment were issued the current bottle and instructed to follow-up with their primary 
3  care providers and/or local health departments so that they can resume treatment. The attached 
4  spreadsheet shows dates of the DAA treatment concluded. (See Exhibit B.)  
5  e.  The number of inmates who obtained SVR (cure) after completion of DAA treatment 
6  during the reporting period 
7  Defendants  report  that  between  April  30,  202,  and  July  14,  2021,  22  inmates  have 
8  obtained SVR. Per Infectious Disease Society of America (https://www.hcvguidelines.org/), SVR is 
9  measured 12 weeks post treatment. Additionally, 2 inmates have completed their treatment while in 
10  custody, but paroled with 12 weeks post-DAA treatment and therefore SVR cannot be verified. 1 
11  inmate completed treatment in April 2021 and was transferred to an out of state facility within 12 
12  weeks post-DAA.  
13  f.  The number of inmates who were tested after receiving DAA treatment but did not 
14  obtain SVR (cure) after completion of DAA treatment during the reporting period 
15  Defendants report that between April 30, 2021, and July 13, 2021, there are no inmates 
16  who have been confirmed to have failed treatment.  
17  g.  The number of inmates for whom DAA Treatment was denied or delayed (with 
18  information and explanations for each denial/delay) during the reporting period. 
19  Defendants report that between April 30, 2021, and July 14, 2021, no inmates have been 
20  denied treatment, however, as set forth more fully below, 14 inmates require further testing and/or 
21  time before treatment can start.   
22  Of the 14 inmates who require further work up: 
23  •  1  inmate  is  refusing  to  change  their  current  seizure  medications  that  are 
24  contraindicated to the current DAA regimen. 
25  •  1 inmate cannot start per Hopes Clinic due to a liver mass. 
26  •  1 inmate is weaning off of contraindicated seizure medications and weaning onto a 
27  new seizure regiment not contraindicated to Hep C treatment.  
28  /// 
 
4 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 103   Filed 08/05/21   Page 5 of 10
 
1  •   9 inmates are pending additional specialist consultations, lab work, and/or imaging 
2  as recommended by Hopes.  
3  •  2 Inmates have completed the required additional imaging or lab work and the 
4  results have been sent to Hopes for review and further evaluation.  
5  Class Counsel have requested further information about these 14 inmates and specifically 
6  whether there is overlap between this group and the group identified in the prior status reports. For 
7  example, in the April 29, 2021 Quarterly Report, there were 10 inmates who were pending further 
8  serological testing before beginning treatment. If 9 of these inmates were still awaiting testing as of 
9  this report, then this could indicate a structural cause of delay that needs to be addressed.  
10  The monitoring information provided by Defendants to Class Counsel includes confidential 
11  information that would merit protection under the Protective Order (ECF No. 43) and the Consent 
12  Decree (ECF No. 80). The Parties have prepared and attached redacted versions of these documents 
13  to this Report and believe that this is appropriate under the above documents and LR IC 6-1. Class 
14  Counsel have received unredacted versions of the documents, but the positions of the Parties are 
15  that these documents need not and should not be made a part of the official court record because it 
16  would require filing under seal.  
17  V.  HCV COMMITTEE MEETINGS AND MINUTES 
18  Under Medical Directive 219, as incorporated into the Consent Decree, “NDOC will 
19  maintain an HCV Committee which shall consist of the Medical Director or designee and at least 
20  two (2) institutional practitioners. The HCV Committee shall meet at least once per month.” MD 
21  219.02(d) (ECF No. 61-1).  
22  Defendants report that the HCV Committee has met on May 5, 2021, June 2, 2021, and 
23  July 14, 2021. Copies of the agendas for May 5, 2021, June 2, 2021, and July 14, 2021 are attached. 
24  Exhibit C. Minutes from the May 5, 2021, June 2, 2021, and July 14, 2021 are attached. Exhibit D. 
25  The NDOC Defendants represent that these minutes reflect approval of all inmates who were 
26  considered for treatment.  
27  /// 
28  /// 
 
5 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 103   Filed 08/05/21   Page 6 of 10
 
1  VI.  UPCOMING DEADLINES FOR THE NEXT QUARTER 
2  Paragraph  37(a)  of  the  Consent  Decree  provides  that  1,200  Class  Members  must  be 
3  provided treatment by October 29, 2021.  
4  Defendants contend that they are largely in compliance with the terms of the consent 
5  decree. Defendants represent that all inmates have been tested, new inmates are being tested, 
6  existing  inmates  are  being  treated,  and  the  Defendants  are  scheduling  pretreatment  screening 
7  appointments as quickly as possible given provider availability.  
8  In  order  to  complete  the  remaining  treatment  by  the  October  29,  2021,  deadline, 
9  Defendants report that the providers at all the institutions have been instructed to start writing 
10  orders for all of the remaining HCV positive inmates immediately. (See Exhibit E ¶ 8 (Declaration 
11  of Dr. Minev, Medical Director)) Defendants will then reserve the limited consultations with the 
12  infectious  disease  specialists  for  those  who  are  medically  unstable  and  require  the  specialty 
13  consultation.  Additionally, the Medical Director instructed that all HCV Protocol labs must be 
14  completed by July 31, 2021. (See Exhibit E ¶ 9) This will allow the order process discussed above. 
15  Class Counsel continue to have significant concerns that Defendants are not on track to 
16  satisfy the October 29, 2021, treatment deadline established in the Consent Decree. In the first 
17  quarter, 15 inmates began treatment. (ECF No. 84, p. 4:15). In the second quarter, 85 inmates began 
18  treatment. (ECF No. 86, p. 4:4-5). In the third quarter, 74 inmates began treatment. Infra. Thus, 174 
19  inmates have  begun treatment  through three-quarters of the year  out of the 1,200 individuals 
20  required to receive treatment after one-year. Defendants have identified approximately 810 inmates 
21  with chronic HCV requiring treatment under the Consent Decree, which would leave approximately 
22  636 inmates who must be treated in the fourth quarter by October 29, 2021. The jump from treating 
23  15, 85, or 74 inmates in a quarter to treating 636 inmates in a quarter appears unlikely to Class 
24  Counsel. Defendants have informed class counsel that they have altered their methodology for 
25  scheduling and administering treatment and have expressed confidence that they will still meet the 
26  deadlines in the Consent Decree, but Class Counsel continue to have the same concerns and have 
27  urged Defendants to take all possible steps to expedite treatment.   
28  /// 
 
6 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 103   Filed 08/05/21   Page 7 of 10
 
1  VII.  EDUCATIONAL PLAN 
2  Information Provided by Defendants 
3  The information contained in the CDC handouts has been added to the television channels in 
4  each institution with that capability. (See Exhibit E ¶ 10.) This information has also been provided 
5  to all inmates who previously opted out of treatment, and will be posted at each institution. The 
6  Medical Director has also found videos produced by the Veteran’s Administration relating to HCV 
7  and providing information to the inmates. These will also be added to the television programing at 
8  the  institutions.  (See  Exhibit  E  ¶  11)  A  copy  of  the  video  may  be  found  at: 
9  https://www.hepatitis.va.gov/products/video-index.asp. This video is being downloaded to DVD 
10  and will be shown at all of the institutions with television capabilities.  (See Exhibit E ¶ 11) The 
11  institutions will also provide information upon intake, for all new inmates.  (See Exhibit E ¶ 5) This 
12  Court asked the Defendants to look into the option for possible group counseling for all of the HCV 
13  positive inmates who have refused treatment or inmates who have refused testing. In discussions 
14  with the Medical Director, that would be difficult, as it would not be possible to counsel inmates in 
15  a group setting while protecting their privacy concerns.  Many inmates do not want their status 
16  made public.  
17  Response from Class Counsel 
18  Class Counsel is pleased that, after being required to do so by the Court, Defendants have 
19  agreed to a meaningful public health educational plan. Further, Defendants have advised Class 
20  Counsel that the provision of additional educational materials has resulted in at least 10 inmates 
21  who have opted-in to HCV testing after initially opting out. Class Counsel is encouraged that the 
22  steps  they  requested,  and  the  Court  endorsed  in  terms  of  providing  inmates  with  a  second 
23  opportunity to receive testing after they receive further education has already yielded successes. 
24  Class Counsel has requested further quantitative data in order to confirm that all of those inmates 
25  who opted out of testing have been provided with the enhanced educational materials and provided 
26  with an opportunity for re-testing.  
27  /// 
28  /// 
 
7 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 103   Filed 08/05/21   Page 8 of 10
 
1  Further, Class Counsel contends that inmates who agree would be able to provide and 
2  participate in peer health education without privacy issues. 
3  Dated August 5, 2021. 
 
4 
   
  AARON D. FORD, Attorney General

documents.text:
Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 123   Filed 11/16/22   Page 1 of 7
 
1  AARON D. FORD 
  Attorney General 
2  D. Randall Gilmer, Bar No. 14001 
  Chief Deputy Attorney General 
3  Douglas R. Rands, Bar No. 3572 
  Senior Deputy Attorney General 
4  Office of the Attorney General 
100 N. Carson Street 
5  Carson City, NV 89701  
(775) 684-1150 
6  (775) 684-1108 (fax)  
drands@ag.nv.gov 
7  drgilmer@ag.nv.gov 
 
8  Attorneys for the  
Nevada Department of Corrections 
9   
 
10  UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
 
11  DISTRICT OF NEVADA 
 
12  * * * * * 
 
13  IN RE: HCV PRISON LITIGATION  Case No:  3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB 
   
14     
  JOINT QUARTERLY REPORT  
15   
 
16   
17    Pursuant to this Court’s Order (ECF No. 79) and the Consent Judgment (ECF No. 80) 
18  (referred to as “Consent Judgment” or “Consent Decree”), Defendants and Class Counsel submit 
19  this Joint Quarterly Report (“Report”) as part of their ongoing monitoring obligations. This Report 
20  does not request relief or other intervention by the Court at this time.  
21  MEMORANDUM OF POINTS AND AUTHORITIES 
22  I.  INTRODUCTION 
23  The Parties believe the consent decree is being followed as envisioned and that there are 
24  no issues that require the Court’s intervention at this time. The Parties also do not believe that a 
25  status check is required this quarter.  
26  The  monitoring  information  provided  by  Defendants  to  Class  Counsel  includes 
27  confidential information that would merit protection under the Protective Order (ECF No. 43) and 
28  the Consent Decree (ECF No. 80). The Parties have prepared and attached redacted versions of 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 123   Filed 11/16/22   Page 2 of 7
 
1  these documents to this Report and believe that this is appropriate under the above documents and 
2  LR IC 6-1. Class Counsel have received unredacted versions of the documents, but do not need to 
3  make these documents part of the court record, requiring filing under seal, unless the Court 
4  disagrees.   
5  For this reporting period, the Parties can represent that the fundamental aspects of the 
6  Consent Decree are in place and are operating as envisioned. The Consent Decree is functioning 
7  to timely and comprehensively provide treatment to inmates in NDOC custody. In the prior 
8  quarter, 1160 inmates were tested for Hepatitis C; 85 inmates tested positive; 104 inmates started 
9  DAA treatment; and 26 inmates were cured after the completion of their DAA treatment.        
10  II.  TESTING AND TREATMENT 
11  Paragraph 32 of the Consent Decree requires Defendants to “test all inmates in the custody 
12  of NDOC for HCV by December 31, 2020.” (ECF No. 80). This has been accomplished by 
13  Defendants, except for some inmates who are currently in the intake process and others who have 
14  recently returned to Nevada from out-of-state facilities. Inmates in these categories are in line to 
15  be tested and will be tested on an ongoing basis.  
16  Paragraph 34 of the Consent Decree requires Defendants to “screen and prioritize all Class 
17  Members using the criteria in the revised version of MD 219.” (ECF No. 80). This has been 
18  accomplished by Defendants, again except for inmates who are currently in the intake process or 
19  who have recently returned to Nevada from out-of-state facilities. Defendants are no longer 
20  prioritizing or sequencing inmates for HCV treatment, which is a positive change that Class 
21  Counsel agrees with.  
22  The Parties have investigated but not identified any changes to the medical standard of care 
23  for HCV that would warrant alterations of the Consent Decree. The HCV Guidelines of the 
24  AASLD and the IDSA were updated on October 24, 2022 and continue to recommend direct-
25  acting antiviral treatment (“Glecaprevir (300 mg) / pibrentasvir (120 mg) to be taken with food for 
26  a duration of 8 weeks; Sofosbuvir (400 mg) / velpatasvir (100 mg) for a duration of 12 weeks”). 
27  https://www.hcvguidelines.org;  https://www.hcvguidelines.org/treatment-naive/simplified- 
28  treatment.  
 
2 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 123   Filed 11/16/22   Page 3 of 7
 
1  III.  ONGOING MONITORING 
2  Paragraph  40  of  the  Consent  Decree  (ECF  No.  80)  requires  Defendants  to  provide 
3  information for the following categories: 
4  a.  The number of inmates tested/screened during the reporting period 
5  Between July 29, 2022 to October 29, 2022, 1160 inmates were tested for Hepatitis C. 
6  Exhibit A. 
7  b.  The number of inmates who tested positive for HCV during the reporting period 
8  (including the date on which each inmate tested positive for HCV) 
9  Between July 29, 2022 to October 29, 2022, 85 inmates tested positive for Hepatitis C.  
10  Please see attached spreadsheet under the tab labeled “POSITIVE” for additional details. Exhibit 
11  B. 
12  c.  The number of inmates who began receiving DAA Treatment (with an indication of 
13  which type of DAA Treatment was provided and the date on which DAA Treatment 
14  was initiated) during the reporting period 
15  Between July 29, 2022 to October 29, 2022, 104 inmates began receiving DAA treatment 
16  for Hepatitis C.  Please see attached spreadsheet under the tab labeled “TX Started” for additional 
17  details. Exhibit C. 
18  d.  The number of inmates who concluded their course of DAA Treatment (with an 
19  indication of which type of DAA Treatment was provided and the date on which DAA 
20  Treatment was concluded) during the reporting period 
21  Between July 29, 2022 to October 29, 2022, 53 inmates concluded their course of DAA 
22  treatment in custody.  Please see attached spreadsheet under the tab labeled “TX Ended” for 
23  additional details. Exhibit D. 
24  e.  The number of inmates who obtained SVR (cure) after completion of DAA treatment 
25  during the reporting period 
26  Between July 29, 2022 to October 29, 2022, 26 inmates were verified to have obtained 
27  SVR after completion of DAA treatment. Exhibit E. 
28  ///  
 
3 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 123   Filed 11/16/22   Page 4 of 7
 
1  f.  The number of inmates who were tested after receiving DAA treatment but did not 
2  obtain SVR (cure) after completion of DAA treatment during the reporting period 
3  Between July 29, 2022 to October 29, 2022, 3 inmates were verified to have NOT obtained 
4  SVR after completion of DAA treatment. Exhibit F.  
5  g.  The number of inmates for whom DAA Treatment was denied or delayed (with 
6  information and explanations for each denial/delay) during the reporting period. 
7  Between July 29, 2022 to October 29, 2022, 44 inmates were denied or delayed.  Please 
8  see attached spreadsheet under the tab labeled “Deny-Delay” for additional details.  Two inmates 
9  have medications contraindicated to DAA treatment.  Six inmates are on-going GI evaluation and 
10  treatment  due  to  various  complications.    Three  inmates  are  pending  infectious  disease 
11  appointments due to previous Hep C treatments and Genotype 3.  Three inmates have their 
12  medications ordered already and they are pending delivery from outside pharmacies.  Two inmates 
13  are pending ultrasounds due to cirrhosis and to rule out liver cancer.  Three inmates are releasing 
14  within 84 days.  Seven inmates were seen by the infectious disease specialist who did not start 
15  treatment due to the offender self-reporting that they will parole within 84 days.  Eighteen inmates 
16  were released before treatment could begin. Exhibit G. 
17  IV.  HCV COMMITTEE MEETINGS AND MINUTES 
18  Under Medical Directive 219, as incorporated into the Consent Decree, “NDOC will 
19  maintain an HCV Committee which shall consist of the Medical Director or designee and at least 
20  two (2) institutional practitioners. The HCV Committee shall meet at least once per month.” MD 
21  219.02(d) (ECF No. 61-1).  
22  The HCV Committee has met on August 3, 2022, September 9, 2022 and October 5, 2022. 
23  Copies of the agendas for August 3, 2022, September 9, 2022 and October 5, 2022 are attached. 
24  Exhibit H. Minutes from the August 3, 2022, September 9, 2022 and October 5, 2022 are attached. 
25  Exhibit I. Defendants represent that these minutes reflect approval of all inmates who were 
26  considered for treatment.  
27  /// 
28  /// 
 
4 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 123   Filed 11/16/22   Page 5 of 7
 
1  V.  UPCOMING DEADLINES FOR THE NEXT QUARTER 
2  This coming quarter will mark the second year of monitoring after entry of the Consent 
3  Decree. Thus, that the Consent Decree requires that NDOC will provide treatment to “an additional 
4  600 Class Members within the second (12) month period after the Effective Date…,” which 
5  deadline would fall on October 29, 2022. (ECF No. 80 ¶ 37(b)). While Defendants only have 
6  provided treatment to One Hundred Nineteen (119) Class Members as of the date of this Report, 
7  this is due to the fact that all possible and medically indicated HCV positive individuals have been 
8  treated and therefore there was no remaining to treat during this timeframe. 
9  Dated November 16, 2022.

  JOINT QUARTERLY REPORT

17
  Pursuant to this Court’s Order (ECF No. 79) and the Consent Judgment (ECF No. 80) 
18
(referred to as “Consent Judgment” or “Consent Decree”), Defendants and Class Counsel submit 
19
this Joint Quarterly Report (“Report”) as part of their ongoing monitoring obligations. This Report 
20
does not request relief or other intervention by the Court at this time.  
21

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 125   Filed 02/21/23   Page 2 of 6
 
1 MEMORANDUM OF POINTS AND AUTHORITIES 
2 I.  INTRODUCTION 
3 The Parties believe the consent decree is being followed as envisioned and that there are 
4 no issues that require the Court’s intervention at this time. The Parties also do not believe that a 
5 status check is required this quarter.  
6 The  monitoring  information  provided  by  Defendants  to  Class  Counsel  includes 
7 confidential information that would merit protection under the Protective Order (ECF No. 43) and 
8 the Consent Decree (ECF No. 80). The Parties have prepared and attached redacted versions of 
9 these documents to this Report and believe that this is appropriate under the above documents and 
10 LR IC 6-1. Class Counsel have received unredacted versions of the documents, but do not need to 
11 make these documents part of the court record, requiring filing under seal, unless the Court 
12 disagrees.   
13 For this reporting period, the Parties can represent that the fundamental aspects of the 
14 Consent Decree are in place and are operating as envisioned. The Consent Decree is functioning 
15 to timely and comprehensively provide treatment to inmates in NDOC custody. In the prior 
16 quarter, 1023 inmates were tested for Hepatitis C; 60 inmates tested positive; 36 inmates started 
17 DAA treatment; and 37 inmates were cured after the completion of their DAA treatment.        
18 II.  TESTING AND TREATMENT 
19 Paragraph 32 of the Consent Decree requires Defendants to “test all inmates in the custody 
20 of NDOC for HCV by December 31, 2020.” (ECF No. 80). This has been accomplished by 
21 Defendants, except for some inmates who are currently in the intake process and others who have 
22 recently returned to Nevada from out-of-state facilities. Inmates in these categories are in line to 
23 be tested and will be tested on an ongoing basis.  
24 Paragraph 34 of the Consent Decree requires Defendants to “screen and prioritize all Class 
25 Members using the criteria in the revised version of MD 219.” (ECF No. 80). This has been 
26 accomplished by Defendants, again except for inmates who are currently in the intake process or 
27 who have recently returned to Nevada from out-of-state facilities. Defendants are no longer 
28
2 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 125   Filed 02/21/23   Page 3 of 6
 
1 prioritizing or sequencing inmates for HCV treatment, which is a positive change that Class 
2 Counsel agrees with.  
3 The Parties have investigated but not identified any changes to the medical standard of care 
4 for HCV that would warrant alterations of the Consent Decree. The HCV Guidelines of the 
5 AASLD and the IDSA were updated on October 24, 2022 and continue to recommend direct-
6 acting antiviral treatment (“Glecaprevir (300 mg) / pibrentasvir (120 mg) to be taken with food for 
7 a duration of 8 weeks; Sofosbuvir (400 mg) / velpatasvir (100 mg) for a duration of 12 weeks”). 
8 https://www.hcvguidelines.org;  https://www.hcvguidelines.org/treatment-naive/simplified-
9 treatment.  
10 III.  ONGOING MONITORING 
11 Paragraph  40  of  the  Consent  Decree  (ECF  No.  80)  requires  Defendants  to  provide 
12 information for the following categories: 
13 a.  The number of inmates tested/screened during the reporting period 
14 Between October 29, 2022 to January 29, 2023, 1023 inmates were tested for Hepatitis C. 
15 Exhibit A. 
16 b.  The number of inmates who tested positive for HCV during the reporting period 
17 (including the date on which each inmate tested positive for HCV) 
18 Between October 29, 2022 to January 29, 2023, 60 inmates tested positive for Hepatitis C.  
19 Please see attached spreadsheet under the tab labeled “POSITIVE” for additional details. Exhibit 
20 B. 
21 c.  The number of inmates who began receiving DAA Treatment (with an indication of 
22 which type of DAA Treatment was provided and the date on which DAA Treatment 
23 was initiated) during the reporting period 
24 Between October 29, 2022 to January 29, 2023, 36 inmates began receiving DAA treatment 
25 for Hepatitis C.  Please see attached spreadsheet under the tab labeled “TX Started” for additional 
26 details. Exhibit C. 
27
28
3 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 125   Filed 02/21/23   Page 4 of 6
 
1 d.  The number of inmates who concluded their course of DAA Treatment (with an 
2 indication of which type of DAA Treatment was provided and the date on which DAA 
3 Treatment was concluded) during the reporting period 
4 Between October 29, 2022 to January 29, 2023, 95 inmates concluded their course of DAA 
5 treatment in custody.  Please see attached spreadsheet under the tab labeled “TX Ended” for 
6 additional details. Exhibit D. 
7 e.  The number of inmates who obtained SVR (cure) after completion of DAA treatment 
8 during the reporting period 
9 Between October 29, 2022 to January 29, 2023, 37 inmates were verified to have obtained 
10 SVR after completion of DAA treatment. Exhibit E.  
11 f.  The number of inmates who were tested after receiving DAA treatment but did not 
12 obtain SVR (cure) after completion of DAA treatment during the reporting period 
13 Between October 29, 2022 to January 29, 2023, 0 inmates were verified to have NOT 
14 obtained SVR after completion of DAA treatment.  
15 g.  The number of inmates for whom DAA Treatment was denied or delayed (with 
16 information and explanations for each denial/delay) during the reporting period. 
17 Between October 29, 2022 to January 29, 2023, 15 inmates were denied or delayed.  Please 
18 see attached spreadsheet under the tab labeled “Deny-Delay” for additional details.  Four inmates 
19 have are being worked up by a gastroenterologist due to complications for treatment (i.e. presence 
20 of a liver lesion, Hep B co-infection, previously treatment of failure). Two inmates were seen by 
21 an infectious disease specialist and no treatment was ordered because one stated they will parole 
22 before treatment would be completed and the other did not believe he has Hepatitis C despite labs 
23 and education. Finally, nine offenders were released during that time period before they could 
24 start. Exhibit F. 
25 IV.  HCV COMMITTEE MEETINGS AND MINUTES 
26 Under Medical Directive 219, as incorporated into the Consent Decree, “NDOC will 
27 maintain an HCV Committee which shall consist of the Medical Director or designee and at least 
28
4 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 125   Filed 02/21/23   Page 5 of 6
 
1 two (2) institutional practitioners. The HCV Committee shall meet at least once per month.” MD 
2 219.02(d) (ECF No. 61-1).  
3 The HCV Committee has met on November 2, 2022, December 7, 2022 and January 4, 
4 2023. Copies of the agendas for November 2, 2022, December 7, 2022 and January 4, 2023 are 
5 attached. Exhibit G. Minutes from the November 2, 2022, December 7, 2022 and January 4, 2023 
6 are attached. Exhibit H. Defendants represent that these minutes reflect approval of all inmates 
7 who were considered for treatment.  
8 V.  UPCOMING DEADLINES FOR THE NEXT QUARTER 
9 This coming quarter will mark the second year of monitoring after entry of the Consent 
10 Decree. Thus, that the Consent Decree requires that NDOC will provide treatment to “an additional 
11 600 Class Members within the second (12) month period after the Effective Date…,” which 
12 deadline would fall on January 29, 2023. (ECF No. 80 ¶ 37(b)). While Defendants only have 
13 provided treatment to Thirty-Six (36) Class Members as of the date of this Report, this is due to 
14 the fact that all possible and medically indicated HCV positive individuals have been treated and 
15 therefore there was no remaining to treat during this timeframe. 
16 Dated February 21, 2023.

  JOINT QUARTERLY REPORT

17    Pursuant to this Court’s Order (ECF No. 79) and the Consent Judgment (ECF No. 80) 
18  (referred to as “Consent Judgment” or “Consent Decree”), Defendants and Class Counsel submit 
19  this Joint Quarterly Report (“Report”) as part of their ongoing monitoring obligations. This Report 
20  does not request relief or other intervention by the Court at this time.  
21  ///

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 121   Filed 08/11/22   Page 2 of 7
 
1  MEMORANDUM OF POINTS AND AUTHORITIES 
2  I.  INTRODUCTION 
3  The Parties believe the consent decree is being followed as envisioned and that there are no 
4  issues that require the Court’s intervention at this time.  
5  The monitoring information provided by Defendants to Class Counsel includes confidential 
6  information that would merit protection under the Protective Order (ECF No. 43) and the Consent 
7  Decree (ECF No. 80). The Parties have prepared and attached redacted versions of these documents 
8  to this Report and believe that this is appropriate under the above documents and LR IC 6-1. Class 
9  Counsel have received unredacted versions of the documents, but do not need to make these 
10  documents part of the court record, requiring filing under seal, unless the Court disagrees.   
11  For this reporting period, the Parties can represent that the fundamental aspects of the 
12  Consent Decree are in place and are operating as envisioned. In fact, Class Counsel are pleased to 
13  report that after working through the logjam of cases, the constraints posed by COVID-19, and 
14  various  other  issues  among  the  parties,  the  Consent  Decree  is  functioning  to  timely  and 
15  comprehensively provide treatment to inmates in NDOC custody. In the prior quarter, 1015 inmates 
16  were tested for Hepatitis C; 77 inmates tested positive; 66 inmates started DAA treatment; and 60 
17  inmates were cured after the completion of their DAA treatment. Class Counsel are especially 
18  pleased to report that these numbers demonstrate that treatment is not being delayed and that the 
19  incidence of Hepatitis C among inmates in NDOC custody continues to decline rapidly.      
20  II.  TESTING AND TREATMENT 
21  Paragraph 32 of the Consent Decree requires Defendants to “test all inmates in the custody 
22  of NDOC for HCV by December 31, 2020.” (ECF No. 80). This has been accomplished by 
23  Defendants, except for some inmates who are currently in the intake process and others who have 
24  recently returned to Nevada from out-of-state facilities. Inmates in these categories are in line to be 
25  tested and will be tested on an ongoing basis.  
26  Paragraph 34 of the Consent Decree requires Defendants to “screen and prioritize all Class 
27  Members using the criteria in the revised version of MD 219.” (ECF No. 80). This has been 
28  accomplished by Defendants, again except for inmates who are currently in the intake process or 
 
2 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 121   Filed 08/11/22   Page 3 of 7
 
1  who  have  recently  returned  to  Nevada  from  out-of-state  facilities.  Defendants  are  no  longer 
2  prioritizing or sequencing inmates for HCV treatment, which is a positive change that Class Counsel 
3  agrees with.  
4  The Parties have investigated but not identified any changes to the medical standard of care 
5  for HCV that would warrant alterations of the Consent Decree. The HCV Guidelines of the AASLD 
6  and the IDSA were updated on September 29, 2021 and continue to recommend direct-acting 
7  antiviral treatment. https://www.hcvguidelines.org.  
8  III.  ONGOING MONITORING 
9  Paragraph  40  of  the  Consent  Decree  (ECF  No.  80)  requires  Defendants  to  provide 
10  information for the following categories: 
11  a.  The number of inmates tested/screened during the reporting period 
12  Between April 29, 2022 to July 29, 2022, 1015 inmates were tested for Hepatitis C.  See 
13  attached spreadsheet “#1 HCV Tested” tab for dates of tests. Exhibit A. 
14  b.  The number of inmates who tested positive for HCV during the reporting period 
15  (including the date on which each inmate tested positive for HCV) 
16  Between April 29, 2022 to July 29, 2022, 77 inmates tested positive for Hepatitis C.  See 
17  attached spreadsheet “#2 HCV Positive” tab for dates of positive tests. Exhibit B. 
18  c.  The number of inmates who began receiving DAA Treatment (with an indication of 
19  which type of DAA Treatment was provided and the date on which DAA Treatment 
20  was initiated) during the reporting period 
21  Between April 29, 2022 to July 29, 2022, 66 inmates started DAA treatment.  See attached 
22  spreadsheet “#3 Treatment Started” tab for dates and treatment names. Exhibit C. 
23  d.  The number of inmates who concluded their course of DAA Treatment (with an 
24  indication of which type of DAA Treatment was provided and the date on which DAA 
25  Treatment was concluded) during the reporting period 
26  Between April 29, 2022 to July 29, 2022, 39 inmates concluded their course of DAA 
27  treatment in custody.  See attached spreadsheet “#4 Treatment Completed” tab for dates and 
28  treatment names. Exhibit D. 
 
3 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 121   Filed 08/11/22   Page 4 of 7
 
1  e.  The number of inmates who obtained SVR (cure) after completion of DAA treatment 
2  during the reporting period 
3  Between April 29, 2022 to July 29, 2022, 60 inmates in custody were confirmed to have 
4  obtained SVR after completion of DAA treatment. Exhibit E.  
5  f.  The number of inmates who were tested after receiving DAA treatment but did not 
6  obtain SVR (cure) after completion of DAA treatment during the reporting period 
7  Between April 29, 2022 to July 29, 2022, 0 inmates in custody were confirmed to have NOT 
8  obtained SVR after completion of DAA treatment. Exhibit F.  
9  g.  The number of inmates for whom DAA Treatment was denied or delayed (with 
10  information and explanations for each denial/delay) during the reporting period. 
11  Between April 29, 2022 to July 29, 2022, 23 inmates were released, 6 inmates currently still 
12  in custody have release dates less than 84 days.  In addition, 10 inmates cannot be treated at this time 
13  pending further imaging/specialty evaluation as recommended by the infectious disease specialist 
14  from the Hopes clinic 7 inmates of whom were previously reported and are still pending to 
15  completion of further imaging/specialty evaluation and 3 inmates have been added this reporting 
16  period. Additionally, by way of explanation, there are some inmates who had their treatment delayed 
17  last quarter that are still delayed this quarter. These 7 inmates are delayed because they require multi-
18  appointment diagnostic follow-up with a gastroenterologist. As a result, their treatment is delayed 
19  but NDOC is working diligently on getting them cleared for treatment once the gastroenterologist 
20  clears them for treatment. Finally, 1 inmate was seen by the infectious disease specialist who 
21  documented during the consultation the inmate opted to delay treatment until he is released in Reno 
22  and 1 inmate told Hopes he was paroling soon and they discussed that he will obtain treatment with 
23  the VA upon parole.  See attached spreadsheet “#7 Delayed or Denied” tab for more detail. Exhibit 
24  G. 
25  IV.  HCV COMMITTEE MEETINGS AND MINUTES 
26  Under  Medical  Directive  219,  as  incorporated  into  the  Consent  Decree,  “NDOC  will 
27  maintain an HCV Committee which shall consist of the Medical Director or designee and at least 
28 
 
4 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 121   Filed 08/11/22   Page 5 of 7
 
1  two (2) institutional practitioners. The HCV Committee shall meet at least once per month.” MD 
2  219.02(d) (ECF No. 61-1).  
3  The HCV Committee has met on May 5, 2022, June 8, 2022 and July 6, 2022. Copies of the 
4  agendas for May 5, 2022, June 8, 2022 and July 6, 2022 are attached. Exhibit H. Minutes from the 
5  May 5, 2022, June 8, 2022 and July 6, 2022 are attached. Exhibit I. Defendants represent that these 
6  minutes reflect approval of all inmates who were considered for treatment.  
7  V.  UPCOMING DEADLINES FOR THE NEXT QUARTER 
8  This coming quarter will mark the second year of monitoring after entry of the Consent 
9  Decree. Thus, it is contemplated that NDOC will provide treatment to “an additional 600 Class 
10  Members within the second (12) month period after the Effective Date…,” which deadline would 
11  fall on October 29, 2022. (ECF No. 80 ¶ 37(b)). Defendants have provided treatment to One Hundred 
12  Nineteen (119) Class Members as of the date of this Report.  
13  Dated August 11, 2022.

documents.text:
Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 97   Filed 06/28/21   Page 1 of 4
 
 
1  Adam Hosmer-Henner (NSBN 12779)

2  Chelsea Latino (NSBN 14227)

11  Class Counsel

UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
13   
DISTRICT OF NEVADA 
14   
* * * * * 
15   
IN RE: HCV PRISON LITIGATION  Case No:  3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB 
16     
 
17  STATUS REPORT 
 
18 
19 
20  Class Counsel submits this Status Report pursuant to the Court’s June 2, 2021 Minute 
21  Order (ECF No. 91), which directed the parties to confer on: “1) communication with inmates 
22  regarding the availability of HCV testing and 2) verification of known instances of HCV due to 
23  concerns about potential discrepancy.” Id.  
24  MEMORANDUM OF POINTS AND AUTHORITIES 
25  I.  INTRODUCTION 
26  Class Counsel have attempted on multiple occasions since June 2, 2021 to communicate 
27  with Defendants’ counsel on the issues raised in Class Counsel’s Response to Status Report (ECF 
28  No. 88) and during the hearing on June 2, 2021 (ECF No. 91), but only received a substantive 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 97   Filed 06/28/21   Page 2 of 4
 
1  response on the afternoon of June 28, 2021. Accordingly, while it does appear that progress is 
2  being made and that there is broad agreement on many items, Class Counsel have not had sufficient 
3  opportunity to assess the efforts of Defendants.  
4  II.  TESTING 
5  Based on correspondence with Defendants’ counsel on June 28, 2021, Class Counsel 
6  understands that Defendants have agreed to provide suggested literature from the CDC to inmates 
7  during their initial opportunity to be tested for HCV as well as to those inmates who have already 
8  opted-out from HCV testing. The latter category will also be provided with a second opportunity 
9  to receive HCV testing. Class Counsel would like to review the actual literature that will be 
10  provided to the inmates as well as to review the procedure for the second round of testing.  
11  Class Counsel is still waiting for a response as to whether Defendants will be able to 
12  provide additional training and education on HCV via group education, closed circuit television, 
13  or other means.  
14  III.  INCIDENCE OF HCV 
15  On June 2, 2021, Class Counsel wrote to Defendants’ counsel: “One suggestion – the most 
16  efficient way to approach this issue may be to identify the inmates who tested positive for HCV 
17  antibodies but who did not receive confirmation of an HCV infection via further PCR testing. If 
18  this number is around ~400-500 then it may explain most of the discrepancy.” It appears that this 
19  hypothesis has been supported by Defendants’ data, but further confirmation and analysis is 
20  necessary. If the incidence of HCV is lower than anticipated, as it appears to be, than the deadlines 
21  of the Consent Decree should be more readily satisfied by Defendants and the operative provisions 
22  to accelerate treatment should go into effect earlier.  (ECF No. 80, ¶ 38) (requiring Defendants to 
23  “provide DAA treatment to Class Members within NDOC’s custody at a rate that, at a minimum, 
24  exceeds the HCV infection rate of new inmates who test HCV positive, or who are confirmed to 
25  be HCV positive during the intake process.)  
26  // 
27  // 
28  // 
 
2 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 97   Filed 06/28/21   Page 3 of 4
 
1  IV.  TREATMENT 
2  The  deadlines  in  the  Consent  Decree  are  fixed  and  Defendants  continue  to  express 
3  optimism that these deadlines will be satisfied. Given the lower than anticipated incidence of HCV, 
4  it is increasingly likely that Defendants will be able to satisfy these deadlines on a timely basis. 
5  First  though,  Class  Counsel  would  like  to  clarify  the  definition  of  “treatment”  to  avoid 
6  misunderstandings as to what constitutes compliance. The Consent Decree defines “DAA” as 
7  “direct-acting  antiviral  medications”  and  establishes  deadlines  for  the  provision  of  “DAA 
8  treatment” to the class members. (ECF No. 80, ¶ 19, 37, 38). Accordingly, Class Counsel believe 
9  that the deadlines are satisfied only when the class members are actually receiving the “direct-
10  acting antiviral medications” in that they have received and taken the first dose. Approval for the 
11  medication, scheduling of further lab tests, or other potential bottlenecks should not qualify as 
12  DAA treatment.  
13  Second, an item of dispute between the sides was the necessity, or lack thereof, of 
14  prioritizing inmates with HCV. While the Consent Decree permits prioritization, any harm of 
15  prioritization was mitigated by the quantitative requirements for the number of inmates who must 
16  receive DAA treatment by certain dates. Given the low incidence of HCV (which means that all 
17  priorities should receive treatment in 2021) and the rapidly approaching deadlines, Class Counsel 
18  believe that any non-essential procedures for prioritization should be suspended in order to 
19  accelerate the provision of DAA treatment. For example, inmates are still being scheduled for 
20  Fibrosure analysis and fibrosis staging even though these tests do not appear to be necessary for 
21  inmates who have already been confirmed to have a viral load. Accordingly, Class Counsel would 
22  like Defendants to suspend any prioritization procedures that are not medically indicated prior to 
23  receiving approval for DAA treatment.  
24  // 
25  // 
26  // 
27  // 
28  // 
 
3 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 97   Filed 06/28/21   Page 4 of 4
 
1  V.  CONCLUSION 
2  Class Counsel will attempt to review information provided by Defendants on June 28, 
3  2021 and provide further analysis and input during the status hearing on June 29, 2021.  
4   
5   
6  Dated June 28, 2021.

Nevada Department of Corrections

10  UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
 
11  DISTRICT OF NEVADA 
 
12  * * * * * 
 
13  IN RE: HCV PRISON LITIGATION  Case No:  3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB 
   
14     
  JOINT QUARTERLY REPORT  
15   
 
16   
   
17  Pursuant to this Court’s Order (ECF No. 79) and the Consent Judgment (ECF No. 80) 
18  (referred to as “Consent Judgment” or “Consent Decree”), Defendants and Class Counsel submit 
19  this Joint Quarterly Report (“Report”) as part of their ongoing monitoring obligations. This Report 
20  does not request relief or other intervention by the Court at this time.  
21  MEMORANDUM OF POINTS AND AUTHORITIES 
22  I.  INTRODUCTION 
23  The Parties believe the consent decree is being followed as envisioned and that there are 
24  no issues that require the Court’s intervention at this time. That being said, Class Counsel has 
25  expressed concerns over the rate of treatment last year versus this year and the issue is that NDOC 
26  has parted ways with many internal providers who were providing HCV treatment. As a result, 
27  NDOC has had to rely more on external care providers which takes additional time to schedule 
28  and facilitate and therefore the rate of treatment this year is not comparable to last year.  
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 119   Filed 05/13/22   Page 2 of 7
 
1  NDOC has scheduled more Hepatitis C clinics, but the status of COVID quarantines and 
2  isolation in large part will drive when the clinics are held. Nonetheless, NDOC believes that it is 
3  still on track to meet the second-year treatment goal contemplated by the consent decree.  
4  The  monitoring  information  provided  by  Defendants  to  Class  Counsel  includes 
5  confidential information that would merit protection under the Protective Order (ECF No. 43) and 
6  the Consent Decree (ECF No. 80). The Parties have prepared and attached redacted versions of 
7  these documents to this Report and believe that this is appropriate under the above documents and 
8  LR IC 6-1. Class Counsel have received unredacted versions of the documents, but do not need to 
9  make these documents part of the court record, requiring filing under seal, unless the Court 
10  disagrees.   
11  For this reporting period, the Parties can represent that the fundamental aspects of the 
12  Consent Decree are in place and are operating as envisioned given the significant constraints that 
13  COVID imposes on the ability for Hepatitis C clinics to be held. Class Counsel continues to be of 
14  the position that COVID is not an excuse for noncompliance with the Consent Decree. There are 
15  no issues that the Parties believe require the Court’s intervention at this time.  
16  II.  REVISED DOCUMENTS 
17  Paragraph 29 of the Consent Decree requires Defendants “to adopt and follow the revised 
18  version of MD 219 . . . and the revised version of the HCV Consent Agreement.” (ECF No. 80). 
19  Defendants have adopted these documents (Medical Directive 219 and Medical Division Form 
20  DOC 2730) as of October 29, 2020 and these documents, along with the Consent Decree were 
21  provided “to all officers, employees, physicians, and agents whose duties might reasonably include 
22  compliance with any provision of this Consent Decree.” Consent Decree, ¶ 28 (ECF No. 80).  
23  III.  TESTING AND TREATMENT 
24  Paragraph 32 of the Consent Decree requires Defendants to “test all inmates in the custody 
25  of NDOC for HCV by December 31, 2020.” (ECF No. 80). This has been accomplished by 
26  Defendants, except for some inmates who are currently in the intake process and others who have 
27  recently returned to Nevada from out-of-state facilities. Inmates in these categories are in line to 
28  be tested and will be tested on an ongoing basis.  
 
2 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 119   Filed 05/13/22   Page 3 of 7
 
1  Paragraph 34 of the Consent Decree requires Defendants to “screen and prioritize all Class 
2  Members using the criteria in the revised version of MD 219.” (ECF No. 80). This has been 
3  accomplished by Defendants, again except for inmates who are currently in the intake process or 
4  who have recently returned to Nevada from out-of-state facilities. Defendants are no longer 
5  prioritizing or sequencing inmates for HCV treatment, which is a positive change that Class 
6  Counsel agrees with.  
7  Class Counsel has also expressed concerns that as class members move in and out of 
8  custody they may not be provided with treatment in all circumstances when the timing would be 
9  feasible. Class Counsel has examined the data and identified 11 inmates who were not treated 
10  because they were scheduled to release prior to October 2021 prior to receiving a full course of 
11  treatment, but then who had returned to NDOC custody by April 2021. This is permissible under 
12  the Consent Decree, but Class Counsel continue to monitor for situations like this where delays in 
13  treatment could result in no treatment for potentially eligible class members. 
14  The Parties have investigated but not identified any changes to the medical standard of care 
15  for HCV that would warrant alterations of the Consent Decree. The HCV Guidelines of the 
16  AASLD and the IDSA were updated on September 29, 2021 and continue to recommend direct-
17  acting antiviral treatment. https://www.hcvguidelines.org.  
18  IV.  ONGOING MONITORING 
19  Paragraph  40  of  the  Consent  Decree  (ECF  No.  80)  requires  Defendants  to  provide 
20  information for the following categories: 
21  a.  The number of inmates tested/screened during the reporting period 
22  Between January 28, 2022 to April 28, 2022, 1,041 inmates were tested for Hepatitis C.  
23  See attached spreadsheet “#1 HCV Tested” tab for dates of tests. Exhibit A.  
24  b.  The number of inmates who tested positive for HCV during the reporting period 
25  (including the date on which each inmate tested positive for HCV) 
26  Between January 28, 2022 to April 28, 2022, 94 inmates tested positive for Hepatitis C.  
27  See attached spreadsheet “#2 HCV Positive” tab for dates of positive tests. Exhibit B.  
28 
 
3 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 119   Filed 05/13/22   Page 4 of 7
 
1  c.  The number of inmates who began receiving DAA Treatment (with an indication of 
2  which type of DAA Treatment was provided and the date on which DAA Treatment 
3  was initiated) during the reporting period 
4  Between January 28, 2022 to April 28, 2022, 42 inmates started DAA treatment.  See 
5  attached spreadsheet “#3 Treatment Started” tab for dates and treatment names.  Exhibit C. 
6  d.  The number of inmates who concluded their course of DAA Treatment (with an 
7  indication of which type of DAA Treatment was provided and the date on which DAA 
8  Treatment was concluded) during the reporting period 
9  Between January 28, 2022 to April 28, 2022, 73 inmates concluded their course of DAA 
10  treatment in custody.  See attached spreadsheet “#4 Treatment Completed” tab for dates and 
11  treatment names. Exhibit D. 
12  e.  The number of inmates who obtained SVR (cure) after completion of DAA treatment 
13  during the reporting period 
14  Between January 28, 2022 to April 28, 2022, 246 inmates were confirmed in custody to 
15  have obtained SVR after completion of DAA treatment. Exhibit E.  
16  f.  The number of inmates who were tested after receiving DAA treatment but did not 
17  obtain SVR (cure) after completion of DAA treatment during the reporting period 
18  Between January 28, 2022 to April 28, 2022, 4 inmates were confirmed in custody to have 
19  NOT obtained SVR after completion of DAA treatment. Exhibit E.  
20  g.  The number of inmates for whom DAA Treatment was denied or delayed (with 
21  information and explanations for each denial/delay) during the reporting period. 
22  Between January 28, 2022 to April 28, 2022, 19 inmates were released, 10 inmates 
23  currently still in custody have release dates less than 84 days and 8 inmates cannot be treated at 
24  this time pending further imaging/specialty evaluation as recommended by the infectious disease 
25  specialist from the Hopes clinic.  See attached spreadsheet “#7 Delayed or Denied” tab for more 
26  detail. Exhibit F.  
27  /// 
28  /// 
 
4 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 119   Filed 05/13/22   Page 5 of 7
 
1  V.  HCV COMMITTEE MEETINGS AND MINUTES 
2  Under Medical Directive 219, as incorporated into the Consent Decree, “NDOC will 
3  maintain an HCV Committee which shall consist of the Medical Director or designee and at least 
4  two (2) institutional practitioners. The HCV Committee shall meet at least once per month.” MD 
5  219.02(d) (ECF No. 61-1).  
6  The HCV Committee has met on February 2, 2022, March 2, 2022 and April 6, 2022. 
7  Copies of the agendas for February 2, 2022, March 2, 2022 and April 6, 2022 are attached. Exhibit 
8  G. Minutes from the February 2, 2022, March 2, 2022 and April 6, 2022 are attached. Exhibit H. 
9  Defendants represent that these minutes reflect approval of all inmates who were considered for 
10  treatment.  
11  VI.  UPCOMING DEADLINES FOR THE NEXT QUARTER 
12  There are no deadlines contemplated during the upcoming quarter. Indeed, because the first 
13  calendar year has passed, the deadlines are based upon a yearly treatment goal instead of a 
14  quarterly triage type goal. As a result, Defendants respectfully request to do away with the 
15  reporting requirement of quarterly deadlines. Class Counsel wish to maintain quarterly reports 
16  because NDOC is not expected to satisfy the quantitative requirements in the Consent Decree, so 
17  unless changes are made to the Consent Decree then there needs to be more oversight rather than 
18  less in order to ensure that treatment is timely provided.  
19  Dated May 13, 2022.

14     
  JOINT QUARTERLY REPORT  
15   
 
16   
17    Pursuant to this Court’s Order (ECF No. 79) and the Consent Judgment (ECF No. 80) 
18  (referred to as “Consent Judgment” or “Consent Decree”), Defendants and Class Counsel submit 
19  this Joint Quarterly Report (“Report”) as part of their ongoing monitoring obligations. This Report 
20  does not request relief or other intervention by the Court as the terms of the Consent Judgment have 
21  been properly carried out to date.  
22  /// 
23  /// 
24  /// 
25  /// 
26  /// 
27  /// 
28  /// 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 117   Filed 02/11/22   Page 2 of 8
 
1  MEMORANDUM OF POINTS AND AUTHORITIES 
2  I.  INTRODUCTION 
3  The Parties believe the consent decree is being followed as envisioned and that there are no issues 
4  that require the Court’s intervention at this time. NDOC believes that it is on track to meet the 
5  second-year treatment goal contemplated by the consent decree. ECF No. 80 ¶ 37. 
6  The  monitoring  information  provided  by  Defendants  to  Class  Counsel  includes  confidential 
7  information that would merit protection under the Protective Order (ECF No. 43) and the Consent 
8  Decree (ECF No. 80). The Parties have prepared and attached redacted versions of these documents 
9  to this Report and believe that this is appropriate under the above documents and LR IC 6-1. Class 
10  Counsel have received unredacted versions of the documents, but do not need to make these 
11  documents part of the court record, requiring filing under seal, unless the Court disagrees.   
12  For this reporting period, the Parties can represent that the fundamental aspects of the Consent 
13  Decree are in place and are operating as envisioned given the significant constraints that COVID 
14  imposes on the ability for Hepatitis C clinics to be held. There are no issues that the Parties believe 
15  require the Court’s intervention at this time.  
16  Class Counsel would like to raise an issue for the Court that will then be addressed next quarter. 
17  Class Counsel is concerned that NDOC will continue to delay treatment until the end of the year 
18  and will not provide treatment on a timely basis. For example, while 96 inmates tested positive this 
19  quarter, only 3 inmates began treatment. This may be a function of NDOC’s push to treat sufficient 
20  numbers by October 2021, but unless ~96 inmates begin treatment in the next quarter, Class 
21  Counsel will request a modification of the Consent Decree to prevent this conduct by NDOC. The 
22  Parties have agreed to meet and confer on this issue.  
23  II.  REVISED DOCUMENTS 
24  Paragraph 29 of the Consent Decree requires Defendants “to adopt and follow the revised version 
25  of MD 219 . . . and the revised version of the HCV Consent Agreement.” (ECF No. 80). Defendants 
26  have adopted these documents (Medical Directive 219 and Medical Division Form DOC 2730) as 
27  of October 29, 2020 and these documents, along with the Consent Decree were provided “to all 
28 
 
2 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 117   Filed 02/11/22   Page 3 of 8
 
1  officers, employees, physicians, and agents whose duties might reasonably include compliance with 
2  any provision of this Consent Decree.” Consent Decree, ¶ 28 (ECF No. 80).  
3  III.  TESTING AND TREATMENT 
4  Paragraph 32 of the Consent Decree requires Defendants to “test all inmates in the custody of 
5  NDOC  for  HCV  by  December  31,  2020.”  (ECF  No.  80).  This  has  been  accomplished  by 
6  Defendants, except for some inmates who are currently in the intake process and others who have 
7  recently returned to Nevada from out-of-state facilities. Inmates in these categories are in line to be 
8  tested and will be tested on an ongoing basis.  
9  Paragraph 34 of the Consent Decree requires Defendants to “screen and prioritize all Class 
10  Members using the criteria in the revised version of MD 219.” (ECF No. 80). This has been 
11  accomplished by Defendants, again except for inmates who are currently in the intake process or 
12  who have recently returned to Nevada from out-of-state facilities. Inmates in these categories will 
13  be prioritized on an ongoing basis. 
14  IV.  Class Counsel’s position on the standard of care is the same as Defendants, and Class Counsel 
15  has not identified any changes to the medical standard of care for HCV that would warrant alterations of 
16  the Consent Decree. The HCV Guidelines of the AASLD and the IDSA were last updated on September 
17  29, 2021, and continue to recommend direct-acting antiviral treatment. https://www.hcvguidelines.org. 
18  Based on these latest updates, which primarily include a switch for elbasvir/grazoprevir (not currently used 
19  by Defendants) from a recommended regiment to an alternative regimen for certain genotypes, no 
20  additional changes are necessary to MD 219.ONGOING MONITORING 
21  Paragraph 40 of the Consent Decree (ECF No. 80) requires Defendants to provide information for 
22  the following categories: 
23  a.  The number of inmates tested/screened during the reporting period 
24     Between November 1, 2021 to January 27, 2022, 1220 inmates were tested for HCV. This 
25  is a combination of intakes and inmates who previously refused and recently consented to be tested. 
26  The attached spreadsheet contains more details. Exhibit A. 
27  b.  The number of inmates who tested positive for HCV during the reporting period 
28  (including the date on which each inmate tested positive for HCV) 
 
3 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 117   Filed 02/11/22   Page 4 of 8
 
1     Between November 1, 2021 to January 27, 2022 96 inmates tested positive for HCV. The 
2  attached  spreadsheet  includes  information  on  the  date  of  each  positive  test.  The  attached 
3  spreadsheet contains more details Exhibit B.  
4  c.  The number of inmates who began receiving DAA Treatment (with an indication 
5  of which type of DAA Treatment was provided and the date on which DAA Treatment was 
6  initiated) during the reporting period 
7     From November 1, 2021, to January 27, 2022, 3 inmates started taking medications. There 
8  have been multiple clinics that needed to be rescheduled to a later date due to an increased number 
9  of COVID cases in the prison population which has caused multiple lockdowns in multiple facilities 
10  and units. However, Hepatitis C clinics have restarted as of January 21, 2022 and we are currently 
11  waiting for the specialist to send NDOC notes and orders to begin more treatments. The attached 
12  spreadsheet contains more details.  Exhibit C. 
13  d.  The number of inmates who concluded their course of DAA Treatment (with an 
14  indication of which type of DAA Treatment was provided and the date on which DAA Treatment 
15  was concluded) during the reporting period 
16     From November 1, 2021 to January 27, 2022, 287 inmates concluded their course of DAA 
17  treatment while in NDOC custody. In addition, 30 inmates would have concluded DAA treatment 
18  between those dates, but they were released and/or paroled mid-treatment. As a result, NDOC 
19  cannot confirm that those inmates completed their treatment. The attached spreadsheet contains 
20  more details. Exhibit D. 
21  e.  The number of inmates who obtained SVR (cure) after completion of DAA 
22  treatment during the reporting period 
23     From November 1, 2021 to January 27, 2022, 59 inmates have obtained SVR after 
24  completion of DAA treatment. Exhibit E.  
25  f.  The number of inmates who were tested after receiving DAA treatment but did 
26  not obtain SVR (cure) after completion of DAA treatment during the reporting period 
27  /// 
28  /// 
 
4 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 117   Filed 02/11/22   Page 5 of 8
 
1     From November 1, 2021 to January 27, 2022, 1 inmate did not obtain SVR after completing 
2  DAA treatment. That inmate was scheduled to see an infectious disease specialist on January 26, 
3  2022. The attached spreadsheet contains more details, Exhibit E.  
4  g.  The number of inmates for whom DAA Treatment was denied or delayed (with 
5  information and explanations for each denial/delay) during the reporting period. 
6     From November 1, 2021 to January 27, 2022, 19 inmates were not treated due for the 
7  following: 
- 9 inmates were released; 
8 
- 6 refused treatment; 
9  - 3 are within 90 days of release; 
- 1 was seen by an infectious disease specialist with Hopes Clinic and the specialist does not 
10  recommend treatment at this time. 
11     The attached spreadsheet contains more details, Exhibit F. 
12  V.  HCV COMMITTEE MEETINGS AND MINUTES 
13     Under Medical Directive 219, as incorporated into the Consent Decree, “NDOC will 
14  maintain an HCV Committee which shall consist of the Medical Director or designee and at least 
15  two (2) institutional practitioners. The HCV Committee shall meet at least once per month.” MD 
16  219.02(d) (ECF No. 61-1).  
17  The HCV Committee has met on November 3, 2021, December 1, 2021 and January 12, 2022. 
18  Copies of the agendas for November 3, 2021, December 1, 2021 and January 12, 2022 are attached. 
19  Exhibit G. Minutes from the November 3, 2021, December 1, 2021 and January 12, 2022 are 
20  attached.  Exhibit  D.  represent  that  these  minutes  reflect  approval  of  all  inmates  who  were 
21  considered for treatment.

5 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 117   Filed 02/11/22   Page 6 of 8
 
1  VI.  UPCOMING DEADLINES FOR THE NEXT QUARTER 
2  There are no deadlines contemplated during the upcoming quarter. Indeed, because the first 
3  calendar year has passed, the deadlines are based upon a yearly treatment goal instead of a quarterly 
4  triage type goal.

13  IN RE: HCV PRISON LITIGATION  Case No:  3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB 
   
14     
                QUARTERLY REPORT  
15   
 
16   
   
17 
18    Pursuant to this Court’s Order (ECF No. 79) and the Consent Judgment (ECF No. 80) 
19  (referred to as “Consent Judgment” or “Consent Decree”), Defendants submit this Quarterly 
20  Report (“Report”) as part of the Court’s ongoing monitoring obligations. This Report does not 
21  request relief or other intervention by the Court as it is the position of the Defendants that the 
22  terms of the Consent Judgment have been properly carried out to date. Class Counsel will issue a 
23  separate response shortly. 
24  /// 
25  /// 
26  /// 
27  /// 
28  /// 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 86   Filed 04/29/21   Page 2 of 8
 
1  MEMORANDUM OF POINTS AND AUTHORITIES 
2  I.  INTRODUCTION 
3  The Defendants are pleased to report that the terms of the Consent Decree are being 
4  satisfactorily implemented and that there are no issues requiring the Court’s intervention at this 
5  time. The Parties have been in communication regarding the implementation of the Consent 
6  Decree and, while this quarter continues to have some difficulties, due to the ongoing COVID 
7  pandemic and its effect on medical appointments, it is not believed that there are any issues that 
8  the Parties have not been able to address and resolve via joint resolution. The Class Counsel has 
9  some questions relating to various issues, and the Defendants, through Counsel, are gathering the 
10  information needed. The Defendants are largely on schedule with respect to the testing and 
11  treatment of inmates for Hepatitis C (“HCV”).  
12  The  monitoring  information  provided  by  Defendants  to  Class  Counsel  includes 
13  confidential information that would merit protection under the Protective Order (ECF No. 43) 
14  and the Consent Decree (ECF No. 80). The Parties have prepared and attached redacted versions 
15  of these documents to this Report and believe that this is appropriate under the above documents 
16  and LR IC 6-1. Class Counsel have received unredacted versions of the documents, but the 
17  positions of the Parties is that these documents should not be made a part of the official court 
18  record because it would require filing under seal.  
19  For the second reporting period, the Defendants represent that the fundamental aspects of 
20  the Consent Decree are in place and are operating as envisioned. In the future, the Parties expect 
21  to be able to provide the Court with further information about the trends in treatment and 
22  practices that can only be gleaned once sufficient data is obtained.  
23  II.  REVISED DOCUMENTS 
24  Paragraph 29 of the Consent Decree requires Defendants “to adopt and follow the revised 
25  version of MD 219 . . . and the revised version of the HCV Consent Agreement.” (ECF No. 80). 
26  Defendants have adopted these documents (Medical Directive 219 and Medical Division Form 
27  DOC 2730) as of October 29, 2020. These documents, along with the Consent Decree, were 
28  provided “to all officers, employees, physicians, and agents whose duties might reasonably 
 
2 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 86   Filed 04/29/21   Page 3 of 8
 
1  include compliance with any provision of this Consent Decree.” Consent Decree, ¶ 28 (ECF No. 
2  80).  
3  III.  TESTING AND TREATMENT 
4  Paragraph 32 of the Consent Decree requires Defendants to “test all inmates in the 
5  custody of NDOC for HCV by December 31, 2020.” (ECF No. 80). All inmates that were in 
6  NDOC’s physical custody as of December 31, 2020 have been tested. Inmates that are new to 
7  NDOC or inmates that have returned from out of state placements are still in the process of being 
8  tested and are being tested on an ongoing basis.  
9  Paragraph 34 of the Consent Decree requires Defendants to “screen and prioritize all 
10  Class Members using the criteria in the revised version of MD 219.” (ECF No. 80). All inmates 
11  with known test results have been prioritized. Inmates that still need be tested, as set forth above, 
12  will be prioritized as the results become known.  
13  The Parties have not identified any changes to the medical standard of care for HCV that 
14  would warrant alterations of the Consent Decree. The HCV Guidelines of the AASLD and the 
15  IDSA were updated on August 27, 2020 and continue to recommend direct-acting antiviral 
16  treatment. https://www.hcvguidelines.org.  
17  IV.  ONGOING MONITORING 
18  Paragraph  40  of  the  Consent  Decree  (ECF  No.  80)  requires  Defendants  to  provide 
19  information for the following categories: 
20  a.  The number of inmates tested/screened during the reporting period 
21  Between January 29, 2021 to April 13, 2021, 806 inmates were tested for HCV. This total 
22  includes both non-intake and intake testing. The intake process takes anywhere between two-to-
23  four weeks to complete, but while these inmates are in the intake process they are being tested 
24  for HCV.  
25  b.  The number of inmates who tested positive for HCV during the reporting period 
26  (including the date on which each inmate tested positive for HCV) 
27  Between January 29, 2021 to April 13, 2021 76 inmates tested positive for HCV. The 
28  attached spreadsheet includes information on the date of each positive test. Exhibit A.  
 
3 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 86   Filed 04/29/21   Page 4 of 8
 
1  c.  The number of inmates who began receiving DAA Treatment (with an indication of 
2  which type of DAA Treatment was provided and the date on which DAA Treatment 
3  was initiated) during the reporting period 
4  Since January 29, 2021, 83 inmates have begun DAA treatment on Epclusa and 2 inmates 
5  began treatment on Mayyret. In addition, 47 inmates have orders to begin medications, with 38 
6  out of 47 with medications on the way to their respective institutions. The remaining 9 out of 47 
7  inmates have medications on their way to Casa Grande Pharmacy to be distributed to their 
8  respective institutions.  
9  d.  The number of inmates who concluded their course of DAA Treatment (with an 
10  indication of which type of DAA Treatment was provided and the date on which 
11  DAA Treatment was concluded) during the reporting period 
12  Since January 29, 2021, 21 inmates on Epclusa have completed their DAA treatment. In 
13  addition, 6 additional inmates on Epclusa are due to complete treatment by April 29, 2021. The 
14  attached spreadsheet shows dates of the DAA treatment concluded. Exhibit B.  
15  e.  The  number  of  inmates  who  obtained  SVR  (cure)  after  completion  of  DAA 
16  treatment during the reporting period 
17  Between  January  29,  2021  and  April  22,  2021,  0  inmates  have  obtained  SVR.  Per 
18  Infectious Disease Society of America (https://www.hcvguidelines.org/), SVR is measured 12 
19  weeks post treatment. 5 inmates will be due to be drawn between April 24, 2021 to April 28, 
20  2021, but the results of those draws are not yet available as of the date of this report. 
21  f.  The number of inmates who were tested after receiving DAA treatment but did not 
22  obtain SVR (cure) after completion of DAA treatment during the reporting period 
23  Between January 29, 2021 to April 22, 2021, 0 inmates have been identified to have 
24  obtained  SVR.  Per  Infectious  Disease  Society  of  America  (https://www.hcvguidelines.org/), 
25  SVR is measured 12 weeks post treatment. 5 inmates will be due to be drawn between April 24, 
26  2021 to April 28, 2021, but the results of those draws are not yet available as of the date of this 
27  report. 
28 
 
4 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 86   Filed 04/29/21   Page 5 of 8
 
1  g.  The number of inmates for whom DAA Treatment was denied or delayed (with 
2  information and explanations for each denial/delay) during the reporting period. 
3  As of April 22, 2021, no inmates have been denied treatment, however, 15 inmates seen 
4  by Hopes clinic require further work ups and 1 inmate has had additional labs and ultrasound 
5  sent to Hopes clinic pending review and recommendations;  
6  Of the 15 inmates who require further work up: 
-  1 inmate needs to wean off Dilantin with the institutional provider due to 
7 
contraindications with HCV treatment,  
8  -  2 inmates who were referred to a gastroenterologist for suspected liver cancer 
(both already scheduled),  
9  -  2 inmates who were referred to have a CT/MRI of the liver (both already 
scheduled),  
10 
-  10 inmates, seen by Hopes clinic, required additional serologic testing and follow 
11  up with Hopes clinic to discuss results prior to initiating treatment. 
12  V.  HCV COMMITTEE MEETINGS AND MINUTES 
13  Under Medical Directive 219, as incorporated into the Consent Decree, “NDOC will 
14  maintain an HCV Committee which shall consist of the Medical Director or designee and at least 
15  two (2) institutional practitioners. The HCV Committee shall meet at least once per month.” MD 
16  219.02(d) (ECF No. 61-1).  
17  The HCV Committee has met on February 3, 2021, March 3, 2021 and April 7, 2021. 
18  Copies of the agendas for February 3, 2021, March 3, 2021 and April 7, 2021 are attached. 
19  Exhibit C. Minutes from the February 3, 2021, March 3, 2021 and April 7, 2021 are attached. 
20  Exhibit D. These minutes reflect approval of all inmates who were considered for treatment.  
21  /// 
22  /// 
23  /// 
24  /// 
25  /// 
26  /// 
27  /// 
28  /// 
 
5 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 86   Filed 04/29/21   Page 6 of 8
 
1  VI.  UPCOMING DEADLINES FOR THE NEXT QUARTER 
2  Paragraph 36 of the Consent Decree provides that by April 29, 2021, Defendants “will 
3  provide DAA Treatment to all inmates who are prioritized as Priority One, as that term is further 
4  defined and described in MD 219, so long as there is no medical contraindication as set forth in 
5  MD 219.” (ECF No. 80). Based on current information, there are 168 inmates who have been 
6  prioritized as Priority One and Defendants are on track for providing DAA Treatment to all of 
7  these 168 inmates by April 29, 2021. However, as further testing is completed and more inmates 
8  are identified as priority one, they will need to be treated. These later identified inmates that are 
9  subsequently  categorized  as  priority  one  cannot  be  treated  by  the  April  29,  2021  deadline 
10  because there will not be enough time between their identification and the start of treatment. 
11  Therefore, the Defendants will seek to provide DAA Treatment to all Priority One inmates 
12  within six months of their identification and prioritization.  
13  Additionally,  the  Defendants  have  also  begun  treating  Priority  Two  inmates  in 
14  anticipation of meeting the one-year treatment deadline for the treatment of all HCV positive 
15  inmates that have not refused treatment.  
16  Dated April 29, 2021. 
 
17 
   
AARON D. FORD, Attorney General
