13  IN RE: HCV PRISON LITIGATION  Case No:  3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB 
   
14     
  DEFENDANTS’ STATUS REPORT 
15   
 
16   
   
17 
18    Pursuant to this Court’s Order (ECF No. 112) and the Consent Judgment (ECF No. 80) 
19  (referred to as “Consent Judgment” or “Consent Decree”), the Defendants submit this status 
20  report regarding Plaintiff’s Response to Quarterly Report. (ECF No. 111) 
21  1.  Updated Educational Information. 
22    The updated medical information was provided to the institutions by Medical Director 
23  Michael Minev on June 25, 2021.  The institutions were instructed to provide this information to 
24  all new intake, and to make it available to all inmates, particularly those who had previously 
25  opted out of testing and treatment. 
26  2.  Updated Refusal Information. 
27  As the Plaintiffs set forth in the Response, supra, “Of the approximately 927 inmates who 
28  have refused testing though, there are approximately 11 who signed two refusals prior to March 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 113   Filed 11/29/21   Page 2 of 5
 
1  24, 2021 during which time the educational information about HCV was inadequate. Thus, these 
2  11 individuals should be provided with the revised educational information and be provided with 
3  a meaningful opportunity to accept testing for HCV. There are a further 202 inmates who signed 
4  two refusals and the latter of the refusals was signed on or after June 28, 2021. An additional 52 
5  inmates only signed one refusal, but which was after June 28, 2021. If Defendants can confirm 
6  that this date was after the provision of revised educational information, then no further action 
7  appears to be warranted for these individuals.”  The date was June 25, 2021.  Therefore, these 
8  inmates have, presumably given their informed consent to refuse.  Many of the remaining inmates 
9  have been given the information, and refused, but the refusal was not documented. Counsel has 
10  instructed the NDOC to ensure that all inmates had a first, second or third opportunity to receive 
11  testing. This information and verification will be provided in the next quarterly report. 
12  3.  The Inmates Who Refused Testing, or Treatment Continue to be Offered Testing or 
Treatment. 
13 
14    The inmates will be offered treatment or testing. As set forth above, the NDOC will 
15  document an acceptance of treatment, or a continued, informed refusal on the inmates who 
16  qualify, medically, for treatment. 
17  4.  Additional Responses to Requests by Plaintiff’s Counsel. 
18    There was some confusion expressed by Counsel regarding the refusal reports.  Plaintiff 
19  noted that there are one or two refusals logged, and others have a date, but a blank refusal date. 
20   On sheet 2, there are several blank refusal dates, but there is a date logged.  According to the 
21  NDOC coordinator, this means NDOC has a refusal form, but the coordinator didn't have the time 
22  to manual type out the actual date of refusal because there were a lot of refusals in one file.  So in 
23  order for him to pull a specific refusal he documented the date he logged the refusal and put that 
24  date on the title of the file itself.  So for example: 
25  Sheet 2 ROW 20 – [Inmate redacted] it has a blank refusal date but a logged date of 2/3/21.  He 
26  would then look in the WSCC refusal folder for a file received from WSCC on 2/3/21.  There are 
27  89 pages in that file.  He would review that file and find [Inmate’s] refusal from 3/13/20. 
28  /// 
 
2 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 113   Filed 11/29/21   Page 3 of 5
 
1  Sheet 2 ROW 24 – [Inmate redacted], also a blank refusal date but logged date of 2/3/21.  Again 
2  he would look in the same file from WSCC logged on 2/3/21 and find [Inmate’s] refusal from 
3  2/18/20. 
4    For the next quarterly report, NDOC will endeavor to update this information, also. 
5  5.  Inmates Released Prior to Treatment, or Prior to Completing Treatment. 
6    Plaintiff’s  counsel  expressed  concerns  about  inmates  released  prior  to  beginning 
7  treatment.  It would not be appropriate to delay release of a prisoner to treat them for HCV.  It is 
8  unlikely that an inmate would agree to stay in prison longer, to receive medical treatment. 
9    As to the 28 inmates with HCV, who were released before treatment could be completed, 
10  parole dates are notoriously fluid.  NDOC takes parole expectation date as the date in which 
11  NDOC calculates that the inmate does not have enough time left (84 days) to complete treatment.  
12  However, parole dates are not readily available and come up unexpectedly.  There were cases, 
13  where inmates were suddenly granted parole, or a parole plan is approved and inmate is paroled 
14  mid treatment.  Even for some inmates NDOC knew that parole was granted, medical had advised 
15  the staff at the institution to discuss it with the inmate first if they want to refuse and seek 
16  treatment outside where they can be treated without interruption or medical would treat if they 
17  consented to taking that risk.  This was done because even though parole was granted, we have 
18  experienced inmates who were granted parole but could not get their parole plan approved and 
19  ended up staying.  NDOC did not want to be caught not treating an inmate because parole was 
20  granted, the inmate ended up having their parole plan rejected, not leaving and now they are 
21  untreated and still in custody without treatment.  Therefore, there were a few instances where 
22  inmates were released mid treatment.  Again, very few inmates would want to remain to complete 
23  their treatment.  However, they were counseled to seek treatment on the outside, to complete the 
24  treatment. 
25  /// 
26  /// 
27  /// 
28  /// 
 
3 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 113   Filed 11/29/21   Page 4 of 5
 
1  6.  New Inmates Who Test Positive. 
2    It is the intention of the NDOC to treat new inmates who test positive or inmates who test 
3  positive while in the custody of NDOC in an expeditious manner.  The NDOC recognizes that this 
4  is a continuing obligation, and intend to operate in good faith to do so. 
5  Dated November 29, 2021. 
 
6  AARON D. FORD, Attorney General

IN RE: HCV PRISON LITIGATION  Case No:  3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB 
16     
   
17    JOINT QUARTERLY REPORT  
 
18   
 
19 
  Pursuant to this Court’s Order (ECF No. 79) and the Consent Judgment (ECF No. 80) 
20 
(referred to as “Consent Judgment” or “Consent Decree”), Class Counsel and Defendants submit 
21 
this Joint Quarterly Report (“Report”) as part of their ongoing monitoring obligations. This Report 
22 
does not request relief or other intervention by the Court as the terms of the Consent Judgment 
23 
have been properly carried out to date.  
24 
// 
25 
// 
26 
// 
27 
// 
28 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 84   Filed 01/29/21   Page 2 of 7
 
1  MEMORANDUM OF POINTS AND AUTHORITIES 
2  I.  INTRODUCTION 
3  The  Parties  are  pleased  to  report  that  the  terms  of  the  Consent  Decree  are  being 
4  satisfactorily implemented and that there are no issues requiring this Court’s intervention at this 
5  point in time. The Parties have been in frequent communication regarding the implementation of 
6  the Consent Decree and, while this first quarter has been an adjustment period, there have not been 
7  any issues that the Parties have not been able to address and resolve. In fact, the Defendants are 
8  largely ahead of schedule with respect to the testing and treatment of inmates for Hepatitis C 
9  (“HCV”).  
10  As this is the first Report, the Parties hope that the format and content are acceptable to the 
11  Court and are of course willing to discuss any feedback, issues, or questions the Court may have 
12  in the event that the Court would like to schedule a status conference. There is one specific item 
13  that the parties would like to identify for the Court related to confidentiality. The monitoring 
14  information provided by Defendants to Class Counsel includes confidential information that would 
15  merit protection under the Protective Order (ECF No. 43) and the Consent Decree (ECF No. 80). 
16  The Parties have prepared and attached redacted versions of these documents to this Report and 
17  believe that this is appropriate under the above documents and LR IC 6-1. Class Counsel have 
18  received unredacted versions of the documents, but do not need to make these documents part of 
19  the court record, requiring filing under seal, unless the Court disagrees.   
20  For this initial reporting period, the Parties can represent that the fundamental aspects of 
21  the Consent Decree are in place and are operating as envisioned. For the next reporting period and 
22  the subsequent periods, the Parties expect to be able to provide the Court with further information 
23  about the trends in treatment and practices.  
24  II.  REVISED DOCUMENTS 
25  Paragraph 29 of the Consent Decree requires Defendants “to adopt and follow the revised 
26  version of MD 219 . . . and the revised version of the HCV Consent Agreement.” (ECF No. 80). 
27  Defendants have adopted these documents (Medical Directive 219 and Medical Division Form 
28  DOC 2730) as of October 29, 2020 and these documents, along with the Consent Decree were 
 
2 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 84   Filed 01/29/21   Page 3 of 7
 
1  provided “to all officers, employees, physicians, and agents whose duties might reasonably include 
2  compliance with any provision of this Consent Decree.” Consent Decree, ¶ 28 (ECF No. 80).  
3  III.  TESTING AND TREATMENT 
4  Paragraph 32 of the Consent Decree requires Defendants to “test all inmates in the custody 
5  of NDOC for HCV by December 31, 2020.” (ECF No. 80). This has been accomplished by 
6  Defendants, except for some inmates who are currently in the intake process and others who have 
7  recently returned to Nevada from out-of-state facilities. Inmates in these categories are in line to 
8  be tested and will be tested on an ongoing basis.  
9  Paragraph 34 of the Consent Decree requires Defendants to “screen and prioritize all Class 
10  Members using the criteria in the revised version of MD 219.” (ECF No. 80). This has been 
11  accomplished by Defendants, again except for inmates who are currently in the intake process or 
12  who have recently returned to Nevada from out-of-state facilities. Inmates in these categories will 
13  be prioritized on an ongoing basis. 
14  The Parties have investigated but not identified any changes to the medical standard of care 
15  for HCV that would warrant alterations of the Consent Decree. The HCV Guidelines of the 
16  AASLD and the IDSA were updated on August 27, 2020 and continue to recommend direct-acting 
17  antiviral treatment. https://www.hcvguidelines.org.  
18  IV.  ONGOING MONITORING 
19  Paragraph  40  of  the  Consent  Decree  (ECF  No.  80)  requires  Defendants  to  provide 
20  information for the following categories: 
21  a.  The number of inmates tested/screened during the reporting period 
22  Between October 29, 2020 to January 28, 2021, 803 inmates were tested for HCV. This 
23  total includes both non-intake and intake testing. There are approximately 147 inmates who are 
24  currently in the intake process who have not yet been tested. The intake process takes anywhere 
25  between two-to-four weeks, but these inmates in the intake process are in the process of being 
26  tested for HCV. In addition to the 147 inmates in or just completing the intake process, NDOC 
27  must test 87 inmates that were transferred back to NDOC custody from Arizona during this time 
28  period. Specifically, those inmates were returned to NDOC custody, and placed in custody at High 
 
3 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 84   Filed 01/29/21   Page 4 of 7
 
1  Desert State Prison (HDSP) throughout the month of November 2020, with transfer completed by 
2  approximately November 30, 2020. NDOC is committed to testing these inmates as soon as 
3  possible, however, due to COVID-19 protocols and other safety and security protocols associated 
4  with the return of these inmates to NDOC custody, they have not yet been tested. However, as 
5  with the other 147 inmates, these inmates are also in the process of being tested. This total does 
6  not include the number of inmates who refused testing and opted-out and the Parties are working 
7  to identify the opt-out statistics and related data.  
8  b.  The number of inmates who tested positive for HCV during the reporting period 
9  (including the date on which each inmate tested positive for HCV) 
10  Between October 29, 2020 to January 28, 2021, 120 inmates tested positive for HCV. The 
11  attached spreadsheet includes information on the date of each positive test. Exhibit 1.  
12  c.  The number of inmates who began receiving DAA Treatment (with an indication of 
13  which type of DAA Treatment was provided and the date on which DAA Treatment 
14  was initiated) during the reporting period 
15  Between October 29, 2020 to January 28, 2021, 15 inmates have begun medication. Exhibit 
16  1. During the same time period, 83 inmates have been seen by a provider and 7 further inmates 
17  were scheduled to be seen on January 29, 2021.   
18  d.  The number of inmates who concluded their course of DAA Treatment (with an 
19  indication of which type of DAA Treatment was provided and the date on which DAA 
20  Treatment was concluded) during the reporting period 
21  Between  October  29,  2020  to  January  28,  2021,  no  inmates  have  concluded  DAA 
22  treatment. The first course of treatment for an inmate who began treatment during the reporting 
23  period is expected to conclude in February 2021. The subsequent Joint Quarterly Report is 
24  obviously anticipated to have more information in this category. 
25  e.  The number of inmates who obtained SVR (cure) after completion of DAA treatment 
26  during the reporting period 
27  Between October 29, 2020 to January 28, 2021, no inmates have obtained SVR for the 
28  reasons explained above in paragraph d.  
 
4 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 84   Filed 01/29/21   Page 5 of 7
 
1  f.  The number of inmates who were tested after receiving DAA treatment but did not 
2  obtain SVR (cure) after completion of DAA treatment during the reporting period 
3  Between October 29, 2020 to January 28, 2021, no inmates have failed to obtain SVR for 
4  the reasons explained above in paragraph d.  
5  g.  The number of inmates for whom DAA Treatment was denied or delayed (with 
6  information and explanations for each denial/delay) during the reporting period. 
7  Between October 29, 2020 to January 28, 2021, Defendants identified a total of 745 
8  inmates as HCV positive. While no inmate has been denied or specifically delayed treatment, there 
9  are 78 inmates releasing within 120 days who will not be eligible for treatment per Medical 
10  Directive 219.03. Exhibit 1.  
11  V.  HCV COMMITTEE MEETINGS AND MINUTES 
12  Under Medical Directive 219, as incorporated into the Consent Decree, “NDOC will 
13  maintain an HCV Committee which shall consist of the Medical Director or designee and at least 
14  two (2) institutional practitioners. The HCV Committee shall meet at least once per month.” MD 
15  219.02(d) (ECF No. 61-1).  
16  The HCV Committee has met on November 4, 2020, December 2, 2020, and January 13, 
17  2021. Copies of the agendas for November 4, 2020 and January 13, 2021 are attached. Exhibit 2. 
18  An agenda for the December 2, 2020 meeting was not prepared. Minutes from the November 4, 
19  2020, December 2, 2020, and January 13, 2021 are attached. Exhibit 3. These minutes reflect 
20  approval of all inmates who were considered for treatment.  
21  // 
22  // 
23  // 
24  // 
25  // 
26  // 
27  // 
28  // 
 
5 
 

Case 3:19-cv-00577-MMD-CLB   Document 84   Filed 01/29/21   Page 6 of 7
 
1  VI.  UPCOMING DEADLINES FOR THE NEXT QUARTER 
2  Paragraph 36 of the Consent Decree provides that by April 29, 2021, Defendants “will 
3  provide DAA Treatment to all inmates who are prioritized as Priority One, as that term is further 
4  defined and described in MD 219, so long as there is no medical contraindication as set forth in 
5  MD 219.” (ECF No. 80). Based on current information, there are 168 inmates who have been 
6  prioritized as Priority One and Defendants are on track for providing DAA Treatment to all of 
7  these 168 inmates by April 29, 2021.  
8  Dated January 29, 2021.
